slides.description:
Welcome to Introduction to Python course!

In this course, we will learn the basics of Python programming language and how to use it to solve various problems.

Throughout the course, we will cover topics such as data types, variables, operators, control structures, functions, file input/output, object-oriented programming, and working with libraries and modules.

We will also explore more advanced topics such as working with APIs, web scraping, and automation.

By the end of the course, you will have a solid understanding of Python programming language and the skills to apply it to real-world projects.

In this section, we will discuss the objectives and outcomes of the course.

By the end of this course, you will be able to write Python programs to solve various real-world problems.

You will have a good understanding of the Python programming language and be familiar with its syntax, data structures, control structures, functions, and object-oriented programming concepts.

You will also be able to work with files, APIs, web scraping, and automation using Python.

Overall, this course aims to equip you with the fundamental skills and knowledge required to start your journey as a Python programmer.

1. Course Overview
2. Getting Started with Python
3. Variables and Data Types
4. Control Flow and Loops
5. Functions and Modules
6. Lists, Tuples, and Dictionaries
7. File Handling and Input/Output
8. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
9. Advanced Topics in Python

Python is what is considered to be a high-level, general interpreted programming language that is dynamically typed and supports a variety of programming paradigms such as procedural programming, object-oriented programming and functional programming.
Originally released in 1991 by Guido van Rossum and is considered to be the most popular programming language used today and one of the easiest to teach individuals.

Setting up your workspace will require a few steps:
 First download/setup the anaconda installer following this link: https://www.anaconda.com/products/distribution
Make sure that you have the bin in your global computer file path.
Make sure you have Jupyter Notebook installed, and you will be able to open jupyter-notebook by typing 'jupyter-notebook' in your command terminal(cmd or terminal).
 Jupyter will be our primary mode of coding in python, so it is imperative that you install it properly and ask me if you have any questions https://jupyter-notebook-beginner-guide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/execute.html#:~:text=1.,will%20contain%20all%20the%20notebooks.

slides.description:
Variable names must start with a letter or underscore, and can be followed by letters, digits, or underscores.
 Variable names are case-sensitive, so 'my_var' and 'My_Var' are two different variables.
 Declaring Variables Using the Assignment Operator '='
 To declare a variable in Python, simply assign a value to it using the '=' operator.
 For example, to declare a variable 'x' with a value of 10, we would write 'x = 10'.
 Understanding Data Types in Python:
 Python supports several data types, including numeric types (integers and floats), strings, and booleans.
 Numeric types represent numbers, strings represent text, and booleans represent true or false values.

Examples of Declaring Variables of Different Data Types
To declare a variable of type integer, we can assign an integer value to it, such as 'x = 5'.
To declare a variable of type string, we can enclose a string value in quotation marks, such as ' name = 'John' '.
To declare a variable of type boolean, we can assign a true/false value to it, such as hasFriends = false or isSad = true

 Unlike in java, python is much more flexible with data types, which is why we have to be much more careful about making mistakes and keeping track of what data types are store in each variable of our own accord.
Commenting your code by typing '#' followed by your comment is an easy way to keep track of what is in what.

Python has several primitive data types, including integers, floats, booleans, and strings.
Integers are whole numbers without a decimal point, while floats are numbers with a decimal point.
Booleans are either True or False and are often used for logical expressions.
Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes, either single quotes('') or double quotes ("").
Additionally, there are two more advanced primitive data types: lists and dictionaries, but we will cover these in depth later. 
Lists are ordered collections of items, and dictionaries are unordered collections of key-value pairs.
These primitive data types form the building blocks of more complex data structures in Python.

Type conversion, also known as casting, refers to the process of converting one data type to another.
In Python, you can convert between primitive data types using built-in functions such as int(), float(), str(), and bool().
For example, you can use int() to convert a string containing a number to an integer, or float() to convert an integer or string to a floating-point number.
Similarly, you can use str() to convert a number to a string, or bool() to convert a value to either True or False.
It's important to note that some conversions may result in a loss of precision or information, so it's always best to use the appropriate conversion function for the desired result.

Here is some sample python code illustrating the capabilities of these functions:
# Converting a string to an integer:
age_str = '27'
age_int = int(age_str)
print(age_int)  # Output: 27

# Converting a float to an integer:
price_float = 9.99
price_int = int(price_float)
print(price_int)  # Output: 9

# Converting an integer to a string:
count_int = 10
count_str = str(count_int)
print(count_str)  # Output: "10"

# Converting a boolean to an integer:
is_true = True
is_false = False
int_true = int(is_true)
int_false = int(is_false)
print(int_true)   # Output: 1
print(int_false)  # Output: 0

# Converting a string to a boolean:
is_true_str = "True"
is_false_str = "False"
bool_true = bool(is_true_str)
bool_false = bool(is_false_str)
print(bool_true)   # Output: True
print(bool_false)  # Output: True (any non-empty string is considered True)

slides.description:
In Python, conditional statements are used to make decisions based on certain conditions.
The most common conditional statement is the "if" statement, which executes a block of code only if a specific condition is true.
In addition to the "if" statement, Python also has "else" and "elif" statements, which are used to create more complex decision-making structures.

# Example 1: if statement
x = 7
if x > 5:
    print("x is greater than 5")

# Example 2: if-else statement
x = 2
if x > 5:
    print("x is greater than 5")
else:
    print("x is less than or equal to 5")

# Example 3: if-elif-else statement
x = 12
if x < 5:
    print("x is less than 5")
elif x > 10:
    print("x is greater than 10")
else:
    print("x is between 5 and 10")

The following code outputs:
x is greater than 5
x is less than or equal to 5
x is greater than 10

# Example 1: For loop
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
for num in numbers:
    print(num)
# Output: 1 2 3 4 5

word = "hello"
for letter in word:
    print(letter)
# Output: h e l l o

# Example 2: While loop
i = 0
while i < 5:
    print(i)
    i += 1
# Output: 0 1 2 3 4
# Example 3: Range function with for loop
for i in range(5):
    print(i)
# Output: 0 1 2 3 4

# Example 4: Enumerate function with for loop
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for i, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(i, fruit)
# Output: 0 apple 1 banana 2 cherry

# Example 5: Zip function with for loop
names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
ages = [25, 30, 35]
for name, age in zip(names, ages):
    print(name, age)
# Output: Alice 25 Bob 30 Charlie 35

# Example 6: Break statement in for loop
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
for num in numbers:
    if num == 3:
        break
    print(num)
# Output: 1 2

# Example 7: Continue statement in for loop
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
for num in numbers:
    if num == 3:
        continue
    print(num)
# Output: 1 2 4 5

In Python, logical operators are used to evaluate logical expressions and return a boolean value of either True or False.
There are three logical operators in Python: "and", "or", and "not".
The "and" operator returns True if both expressions being evaluated are True, otherwise it returns False.
The "or" operator returns True if at least one of the expressions being evaluated is True, otherwise it returns False.
Finally, the "not" operator returns the opposite boolean value of the expression it is evaluating.
Logical operators are often used in conditional statements such as "if" statements and "while" loops to control program flow based on logical conditions.
They can also be used in conjunction with comparison operators to create more complex logical expressions.
Overall, logical operators are an essential tool for writing programs that can make decisions based on logical conditions.Here are some examples:
a = 5
b = 10
c = 15

# using AND operator
if a < b and b < c:
    print("Both conditions are true.")
# output: Both conditions are true.

# using OR operator
if a < b or a > c:
    print("At least one condition is true.")
# output: At least one condition is true.

# using NOT operator
if not(a > b):
    print("a is not greater than b.")
# output: a is not greater than b.
